how we can take anatomical reference and
modify it so that we can begin to create
unique characters from our imagination
we'll modify a few parameters of our
reference the first is going to be the
size of our anatomical shapes now you
don't want to just enlarge everything or
shrink everything down you want to
create some contrast in your designs so
we're going to focus on creating small
medium and large shapes and since we're
modifying the size of our shapes we're
also going to have to adjust the pose
since you're shifting the weight and
balance you'll see in the first section
that I create a lot of these brutish
looking torsos that are very large
almost orcish and as a result I pulled
the torso forward so that counterbalance
is that added weight and finally we'll
adjust the quality of our shapes that
being its squareness circularity or
triangularity this exercise is really
going to challenge your anatomy
knowledge so if you're not comfortable
with it be sure to refer to texts like
Bridgman and do some figure drawing
beforehand and if you want to do this
exercise but still don't feel too
comfortable with your figure drawing
just choose a simpler subject and have
some fun playing around with the shapes
you can always go for a more simplified
pixar like style
before I begin any one of these sketches
I decide beforehand which anatomical
feature is going to be small medium or
large
this way when I go into the sketch I
have an idea of the direction I'm
heading in and I'm not just aimlessly
sketching until I find something just as
I mentioned in my deciphering Bridgman
series it's important that your lines
show the underlying volumes and the
overlapping of anatomical forms
you'll see me doing this in a couple
areas already you can see the deltoid
muscle is coming towards the center of
the arm the latissimus muscle on the
back is overlapping the external oblique
and the ribcage and the rectus abdominis
muscle which is that main abdomen muscle
is overlapping that far shape that
you're seeing for the ribcage
overlapping shapes is one of the best
ways to create depth and perspective I'm
also really keen on distinguishing the
shapes of muscles tendons and bones so
you'll see that my muscles get a more
rounded shape the tendons are a little
bit more linear and my bones are very
sharp and pointed in addition to that
I'm also trying to distinguish between
flexed and stretched muscles so you can
see that all of my tricep shapes are
really pointed and sharp whereas the
bicep shape is usually a little bit
longer since the arm is in a more
extended position that tricep is going
to be more flexed than the bicep is so
again that shape gets more rounded and
condensed whereas that bicep shape is
just elongated you can also see that
since I'm making all of these torsos
more top-heavy than the reference I'm
shifting the ribcage in the opposite
direction of its natural alignment I
used reference of gorillas to find a
more interesting and creature like
posture for all of these and since I
knew this one was going to have large
forearms it seemed only fitting to
completely shift the posture

as far as the mechanics of my sketching
I've typically draw in shapes somewhat
loosely I then try to think of every
line I make as indicating a shadow and
so I tend to place my lines where the
value is darker although I don't like to
over render my drawings I always like
each form to look as though it has a
light side and a shadow side I also
imagine my lines as doubling as edges in
painting where there's a very crisp
solid line that represents a hard edge
in a painting so a very clear shift in
values and where I tend to taper my
lines off that functions as a soft edge
so it's easier to indicate a rounded
surface by feathering out my line work
what's also really nice about doing
exercises like this is you can build up
this repository of anatomies that you
can use when designing characters and
for those that are always concerned
about the ethics of using reference this
is a particularly useful example of how
you can take reference and not directly
copy it that being said I really just
want to emphasize that all artists do
use reference especially if you're in
the earlier stages of the learning
process there's no way that you can
expect yourself to be able to draw
things that resemble reality without
studying reality first and if you think
about the combined number of tasks that
you're undergoing when trying to design
a character you're simultaneously trying
to draw Anatomy which some people spend
their entire lives just improving their
ability to draw the figure and on top of
that you're trying to make characters
that have unique shapes posture
costuming and a unique backstory so it's
no wonder that we're gonna hit a ton of
roadblocks along the way hopefully you
can see how helpful it was just to take
this one reference image and modify the
hell out of it it's a really exciting
exercise and I highly suggest you do it
with a bunch of different references and
anatomical features
